I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations

What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List:
Basics of tropical field research! 
How to identify tropical plants, birds, insects
How tropical ecosystems and forest systems function
I learned a lot about writing scientifically and the process of peer review. Also, how to write collaboratively.
I learned how to better ID tropical trees, insects and animals. I also learned how to effectively collect data, analyze results and discuss their meaning.
Enhanced my skills in field work in tropical forests and in Latin America.

In field: some tree ID, experiment design, data collection experience 

In class: writing skills, statistical skills, peer review practice

I learned a lot about the structure and variety of tropical forests. I also learned a lot about some differences between fieldwork in the tropics and temperate areas. Lastly, I learned a lot about Panama.
Tropical field research methodology that can be extrapolated to other biomes. Writing research papers and peer reviewing.
basic research skills - how to form a research question, develop methods to test it, and carry out a field study.
Above and beyond! I learned so much more than I thought I would, it was one of the best experiences I've had.

The resources provided in class and on canvas for how to write science papers and do peer review were really very helpful and I saved them for future use.  Especially formal peer review, which I had never really done before in this kind of scenario - like beyond just grammatical edits.
I learned exactly what I expected to learn.
Very well.
Very well. The field component was excellent and it was a good learning experience to write up our papers.
It aligned with my expectations.
Well aligned.

The course is super organized and planned out, sticks to the schedule, and is designed to build up to your final project in a cohesive way.

Honestly, too many people took this course for a trip to Panama and then didn't care to put the work into the actual classwork and it made things difficult.

Strengths - hands-on experience, professors, deliverables
Weaknesses - lectures

The strength is the field trip. For the field trip, I would have liked to spend more time learning about what kind of research goes on at STRI and if possible talk to those researchers about their methods. I think I would have learned more than by only designing our own study. Another weakness is that people have different levels of experience with designing, carrying out, and writing about research. Some people were ahead, and some were behind (but I'm not sure how that could be improved). Finally, it would have been great to get feedback on our scientific writing so that we could improve it for next time.

I'm not sure how this could be implemented, but it would be cool to be able to do some research and plan a project before going to Panama. I guess this could be done if the trip was over the spring, but I'm not sure how it would be done with a winter trip. It might be helpful to have a bit more guidance in choosing a project topic. Maybe Liza and Simon could roughly outline some general ideas for students to expand upon.
The course needs more meaning behind the research so that students are more motivated and excited to work with each other.

The strength of this course is definitely the trip to Panama. The only way to properly learn about tropical field ecology is to be in the tropics! A potential weakness of the course was having to write group lab reports. I know that Liza and Simon decided to have us write group lab reports to understand about the difficulties of collaboration when writing papers, but it was a bit hard because some people in the groups had never written a lab report before. That meant that the people that had written lab reports before shouldered most of the work.
Well organized. Professors with  experience.
Absolutely!!! Amazing class and amazing professors. Definitely one of my favorite classes at Yale.

Enjoy the trip and take in as much information as you can, but don't take it if the goals of the actual course aren't important to you.  It can be really meaningful or it can be a waste of other people's time.
Take it!
Be prepared for field work. Liza is always right!

This is a great courses with a wonderful field component. You don't have to be a tropical forester/ botanist/ ecologist to take this class as long as you are interested in the material and excited about seeing the process of conducting tropical ecology research. Be aware that while this class does have very little scheduled hours over the actual semester, it still does require a lot of time.
Take it if you are interested in the tropics!
